People are happy when the weight lifts, / not all at once, but like fog burning off fields at dawn. / When the coffee steams and the radio plays that song— / the one that knows your name. / They’re happy in bus stops and laundromats, / in shared smiles over dropped gloves, / in the way bread rises without hurry or shame. / Happy is the quiet yes after years of no, / the first unafraid breath after a storm has passed. / It’s in the garden where hands dig into soil, / planting hope in wrinkled seeds. / People are happy when they are seen— / not fixed, not judged, just known. / When silence isn’t empty, but full of presence. / They’re happy in kitchens humming with soup and stories, / in letters written but never sent, / in bare feet on cool grass at midnight. / Happiness isn’t loud; it’s the hush between heartbeats. / It’s not earned. It arrives— / uninvited, unannounced— / and whispers, 'You’re here. That’s enough.'

People are happy when they stop chasing the horizon, / when they sit beneath a tree and let the shade name them. / When the grocery list is forgotten, and they buy flowers instead. / Happy is the dog’s wag, the cat’s slow blink, / the toddler who insists on walking in rain puddles. / It’s in the crumpled receipt with a doodle, / in the book left open on the couch, / in the way steam rises from a bowl of soup like a prayer. / People are happy when they forget to perform, / when pajamas stay on past noon, / when they sing off-key in the shower just because. / It’s not in winning, but in trying— / in the paint smeared on fingers, / in the poem that doesn’t rhyme. / Happy is the moment you realize you’re not alone, / even when you’re alone. / It’s the neighbor who waves from across the street, / the barista who remembers your order. / People are happy when they breathe deep and say, / 'This, too, is enough.'

People are happy when the world slows— / when the clock forgets to tick, / when the sky paints itself in watercolor pinks. / They’re happy in shared silence on a porch swing, / in the weight of a cat curled on a lap, / in the first sip of cold water on a hot day. / Happy lives in the margins— / between tasks, between thoughts, / in the pause before saying 'I love you.' / It’s in the crinkle of eyes, not just smiles, / in the way old couples still reach for each other’s hands. / People are happy when they release the need to be extraordinary, / when they embrace the softness of being ordinary. / It’s in burnt toast and second chances, / in mismatched socks and untied shoelaces. / Happy is not a destination, but a direction— / a turn toward light, however faint. / It’s in the courage to be still, / to listen to the quiet hum of being. / People are happy when they remember / that joy doesn’t demand perfection— / it thrives in the cracks.

People are happy when they find each other— / in crowded subways, in quiet libraries, / in the hush of hospitals holding hands. / They’re happy in small rebellions: dancing barefoot in the kitchen, / wearing sunglasses indoors, / saying 'yes' to dessert first. / Happy is the dandelion growing through concrete, / the letter found in a secondhand book, / the stranger who returns your wallet with cash intact. / It’s in the smell of rain on dry earth, / in the dog’s frantic tail at the sound of your voice, / in the way children believe in magic. / People are happy when they stop measuring worth in productivity, / when they let tears fall without apology. / Happy is the deep breath after grief, / the first laugh after loss. / It’s not constant, but it’s constant enough. / People are happy when they remember they are part of something— / a web of moments, of connections, / of small, shimmering, ordinary grace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy when the morning spills gold through the blinds, / when coffee steams in chipped mugs and the world feels kind. / A child’s laugh tumbles down the stairs, / a dog wags its tail without cares. / Happiness hums in small, quiet things— / the way a name is called, the joy a letter brings. / It’s not in palaces or vaults of wealth, / but in shared bread, in true health. / In hands that hold when storms draw near, / in voices saying, “I’m glad you’re here.” / It blooms in gardens we tend each day— / in seeds of kindness we gently lay. / People are happy when they feel seen, / when silence isn’t cold, but serene. / When burdens are halved and joys doubled, / when hearts are open and troubles muddled. / It’s not a shout, but a steady glow, / a candle lit in the evening’s slow. / A hum in the kitchen, a book well-read, / a path through woods where thoughts are fed. / People are happy not because life’s perfect, / but because love persists, and connections connect.

People are happy when the sky stretches wide, / and clouds drift like thoughts with nothing to hide. / When bare feet press into warm summer earth, / and music plays for no commercial worth. / It’s in the pause between words well-spoken, / in promises kept, in hearts unbroken. / A shared umbrella in a sudden rain, / two strangers smiling, easing the strain. / Happiness isn’t loud or bought or sold— / it’s found in stories quietly told. / In grandparents’ hands, wrinkled and wise, / in children’s eyes, bright with surprise. / It lives in gardens, in bread that rises, / in long slow sunsets and fireflies. / In letters written, not emails sent, / in time well spent, not time misspent. / People are happy when they belong, / when they know their voice has a rightful song. / When laughter echoes down hallways long, / and the night sings lullabies gentle and strong.

People are happy in the hush of dawn, / when worries fade and hope is drawn / in soft light across the floor. / They’re happy knocking on a neighbor’s door / just to say hello, to share a smile— / no hurry, no agenda, just for a while. / It’s in the rhythm of a rocking chair, / in knowing someone’s always there. / In soup shared when someone’s ill, / in climbing hills just for the thrill. / Happiness hides in plain view— / a red balloon, a sky so blue, / a cat curled up in a sunlit square, / the way the wind combs through your hair. / It’s not in chasing, not in gain, / but in quiet moments, again, again. / People are happy when they’re free— / not from duty, but from apathy. / When they plant a tree they’ll never see grow tall, / and give without counting, giving their all.

People are happy when they dance alone, / in kitchens humming a favorite song. / When letters arrive in handwriting known, / and memories rise, tender and strong. / It’s in the smell of rain on dry ground, / in a well-worn book, in familiar sound. / In helping a stranger tie a loose shoe, / in saying “I see you,” and meaning “I know you.” / Happiness isn’t a destination, a prize, / but woven in glances, in soft goodbyes. / In a teacher’s nod, in a worker’s rest, / in a mother’s breath when her child is blessed. / It’s in the courage to be who you are, / beneath both sun and thunderstorm’s scar. / People are happy when they care deeply, / when love is lived, not just believed. / When they mend what’s torn, when they grow their own food, / when gratitude is understood. / Not in having everything, but in needing less— / in finding joy in what’s nonetheless.

People are happy when the stars come out, / and streetlights flicker with a golden shout. / When dinner is simple, but shared with friends, / and the conversation never ends. / It’s in the weight of a well-held hand, / in footprints side-by-side in the sand. / In singing off-key, in jokes that fall flat, / in forgiving the grudges we carry and that. / Happiness isn’t flawless or grand— / it’s built grain by grain, like castles in sand. / In planting flowers where there was a crack, / in turning back when you’re on the wrong track. / People are happy when they listen well, / when they ring the truth of their own bell. / When they dance in the kitchen, when they write bad poems, / and still feel at home in their own skins and bones. / It’s in the courage to start again, / in small rebellions against “should” and “then.” / People are happy not because life is easy, / but because love makes even the hard things seem peaceful.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy when the morning spills gold through the blinds, / when coffee steams in chipped mugs and the kettle sings its bright tune. / A child laughs in pajamas, chasing light across the floor, / and the dog wags his whole body, ecstatic for scraps and love. / Happiness lives in small rooms, in worn socks and open windows, / where the air hums with the ordinary music of being known. / It’s not in distant lands or bank accounts, but in the way a hand / brushes yours while reaching for the bread, or how a voice says, / 'I saved you the last piece.' People are happy / when they forget to notice it—when joy slips in unnoticed, / like sunlight on dust motes, like breath after a long cry. / It’s in the quiet yes of staying, of sharing, of simply being here, / where the world is not fixed but held, and love is a language / spoken in glances, in silence, in soup shared on a Tuesday night.

People are happy beneath the weight of routine, / where the rhythm of laundry, commutes, and grocery lists / becomes a lullaby. They are happy in parks / where pigeons strut and old men play chess without speaking, / in the way strangers smile when a baby giggles on a bus. / Happiness is not always loud; sometimes it’s the hum / of a refrigerator, the crinkle of a newspaper, / the certainty that someone will call at seven. / It’s in the warmth of a shared umbrella, the comfort / of a favorite sweater, the dog’s tail thumping at the door. / People are happy when they are not chasing happiness, / when they are simply present—stirring soup, tying a shoe, / watching clouds shape-shift above the rooftops. / It’s the unremarkable moments that stitch the soul together, / threads of peace woven through the fabric of days. / People are happy when they remember / that joy doesn’t demand grandeur—only attention.

People are happy in gardens, where hands dig into soil / and something green answers back. They are happy / when they grow things—tomatoes, tulips, trust— / when they witness life rise from what seemed dead. / A grandmother hums as she ties up vines, / her fingers stained with earth and memory. / Children press seeds into soft ground, believing / in miracles too small to measure. / Happiness blooms where patience is practiced, / where we accept rain and wait for sun. / It’s in the taste of a sun-warmed strawberry / picked and eaten right off the stem, / in the quiet pride of a row well-tended. / People are happy when they nurture, / when they remember they are part of a cycle— / planting, tending, harvesting, resting. / The garden teaches: joy is not found, / but grown.

People are happy when they sing off-key in the shower, / when they dance in kitchens with no one watching, / when they write bad poetry and call it truth. / They are happy in acts of gentle rebellion— / skipping a meeting to walk in the rain, / buying flowers just because the color called their name. / Happiness hides in defiance of urgency, / in choosing softness over speed. / It’s in handwritten letters, in phone calls with no agenda, / in saying 'I miss you' without shame. / People are happy when they let themselves be silly, / when they wear mismatched socks and laugh at their own jokes. / It’s in the courage to be unproductive, / to sit and stare at the sky and call it sacred. / Joy arrives when we stop performing / and start living—messy, tender, gloriously imperfect. / People are happy when they forget to impress / and remember to express.

People are happy in the hush between words, / when silence isn’t empty but full—of understanding, / of presence, of love that doesn’t need translation. / They are happy in hospitals holding hands, / in doorsteps at midnight with tea and sorrow, / in the way a friend knows when not to speak. / Happiness isn’t always joy; sometimes it’s relief, / the deep breath after grief, the light returning / after long darkness. It’s in resilience, in community, / in the circle of arms around someone breaking. / People are happy when they are not alone, / when they are seen in their cracks and called beautiful. / It’s in shared meals after funerals, in songs sung softly, / in the quiet miracle of healing. / People are happy when they belong— / not perfectly, but truly.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text: Fire: a tongue that speaks without sound, licking the dark with urgent red. It breathes in gasps of smoke and sighs of ash, a living hymn to hunger. It does not ask—it takes. It does not wait—it consumes. In its core, a pulse like a heart forged in chaos, beating time to ancient rhythms older than bone. It dances on logs and licks the sky, painting dusk in its own image. Once, it warmed caves and kept wolves at bay. Now, it melts steel and fuels rockets. Still, it remembers the forest floor, the dry leaf, the spark that starts the song. I have seen it in eyes—not just in rage, but in resolve, in love too fierce to name. Fire is not evil. Fire is not good. It simply is: a force that refuses stillness. We need it. We are made of the same brief, burning.

Fire: a word that cracks the air like a whip. One syllable, one strike—lightning caught in language. It begins as a thought: a match struck against doubt, a spark in the hollow of night. Then, the roar. The leap. The wild gold spreading like rumor. It devours paper, wood, years—converting memory to ember. It is both destroyer and midwife: from its ashes, green shoots whisper defiance. I have warmed my hands in its grace and flinched from its wrath. It flickers in campfires where stories are born, and in furnaces where wars are forged. Fire teaches no mercy, yet offers warmth. It does not judge—it simply burns. And in its glow, faces soften, shadows stretch like dancers. We are drawn to it, not despite its danger, but because of it. Fire reminds us we are alive—brief, bright, and burning. Even stars are fire, distant and cold to touch, yet lighting the void. So let me be fire: not reckless, but real. Let my words ignite. Let my soul hold light.

Fire: the first god we ever served. We knelt not in prayer, but in need—shivering, small, beneath vast night. Then came flame, and we stood taller. It pushed back the dark, cooked the raw, scared the unseen teeth in the brush. We carried it like a child, fed it tenderly, feared its tantrums. It gave us time: no longer slaves to daylight, we shaped stories in its flicker. But fire does not care for gratitude. It leaps fences, swallows homes, writes obituaries in soot. It is indifferent, beautiful, terrible. In labs, we split its cousins—atomic fire, silent and vast—capable of powering cities or erasing them. Still, we light candles for the dead, bonfires for joy. Fire lives in us: the fever of illness, the burn of shame, the glow of passion. It is the engine of digestion, the spark behind thought. We are creatures of controlled combustion. To live is to burn slowly. To love is to kindle. And when we die, fire often has the final word—reducing bone to dust, returning us to the cycle. Fire: neither friend nor foe, but the oldest force we know.

Fire: a verb before it was a noun. It does. It acts. It doesn’t wait for permission. It climbs walls like a rebel, devours oxygen like a starving king. Or thought we did. But fire cannot be owned. It can only be borrowed, briefly, behind glass or stone. It escapes. It spreads. It remembers freedom. I’ve seen it in riots, in hearths, in the eyes of someone who’s had enough. Fire doesn’t negotiate. It transforms. What was solid becomes gas, becomes ash, becomes memory. It doesn’t apologize. It doesn’t explain. It burns. And when it’s gone, it leaves a silence that hums. We build monuments to last, but fire reminds us: all things end in light. Even the sun will cool. But for now, we gather around its glow—hands outstretched, faces lit, souls warmed by chaos tamed, if only for a moment. Fire: the original revolution.

Fire: a paradox wrapped in light. It gives warmth and takes life. It cooks our food and cremates our dead. It powers engines and incinerates cities. Now we know it’s fusion, physics—but still, it feels divine. Fire doesn’t sleep. It flickers, it rages, it dies down to embers that pulse like dying hearts. It is change made visible: the log becomes flame becomes ash. Nothing is lost, only transformed. Even grief is a kind of fire—consuming, painful, necessary. And love? Love is fire that chooses not to burn. It warms, it sustains, it illuminates. But let it rage unchecked, and it destroys. So we tend our fires—of hearth, of heart, of purpose—with care. We feed them wisdom, not just fuel. For fire, once lit, must be respected. It does not forget. It does not forgive. It simply burns.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text: Under a shroud of indigo sky, the night funeral begins—no sun dares intrude. Lanterns flicker like dying breaths along the cobbled path, casting long silhouettes that bow in silent prayer. The cypress trees stand as pallbearers, solemn and still, their shadows draping the earth like mourning veils. The grave yawns open, a mouth waiting to swallow memory whole. As the body descends, the stars blink once—acknowledgment, not comfort. In this hour, grief wears no face; it is the hush between heartbeats, the cold on the nape, the echo of footsteps walking home alone. The night funeral does not end—it lingers, stitched into the fabric of dreams, where the dead speak in sighs and the living learn the weight of absence.

Night funeral—two words that taste like ash and silence. The moon, a sliver of bone, watches from above as the procession moves like smoke through the graveyard. No hymns, only the low chant of crickets and the occasional sob stifled by a handkerchief. The earth is damp, the air thick with the scent of wet roses and decay. A mother clutches a locket; a child asks why the sky is so dark. No one answers. The casket is lowered with ropes that groan like old grief. Fireflies drift above the graves, mistaken for souls by the hopeful. But hope has no place here. This is where love goes to rot, where names fade into stone. And yet, in the stillness, a single daffodil trembles—proof that life, however fragile, refuses to be buried. The mourners disperse, shadows dissolving into shadow. Only the wind remains, whispering eulogies to the dirt. Night funeral: not an end, but a folding inward, a secret kept by the soil.

Beneath the hush of a moonless dome, the night funeral unfolds in whispers. A raven calls once, a croak like a cracked bell. Someone drops a rose; it rolls into the open grave and vanishes. The stars, indifferent, blink in their cold constellations. There is no resurrection here, only surrender. The earth is shoveled back with a sound like time closing its jaws. When the last mourner leaves, the silence swells, thick and eternal. But in the roots below, something stirs—memory, perhaps, or the slow work of transformation. Night funeral: where death wears a velvet mask and the world holds its breath.

The night funeral is a secret the village keeps. They come after dusk, when work is done and children are asleep, slipping through back paths to the old cemetery on the hill. An old woman sings a lullaby in a dialect long forgotten, her voice cracking like dry leaves. The stars above seem closer tonight, watching like ancestors. As the grave is filled, each person places a stone upon the mound—a tradition older than memory. No names are spoken. No tears fall. By morning, the mound will be smooth, the stones arranged in a circle, and the world will pretend it never happened. But the wind will carry the lullaby for weeks, and dogs will howl at nothing. Night funeral: a rite of shadows, where the dead are not mourned, but returned.

Night funeral—held when the world is asleep, so grief need not wear a polite face. The hearse glides without headlights, guided by instinct and sorrow. A poem is read, but the wind steals half the lines, scattering them into the trees. The coffin, made of unvarnished wood, is lowered with care, as if the dead might still feel a jolt. A single violin plays a melody with no name, looping back on itself like time in a dream. Someone laughs—a nervous, broken sound—and then silence swallows it whole. When the last shovelful of dirt is placed, no one moves. They stand, breathing in unison, tethered by loss. Then, slowly, they turn and walk away, their shadows stretching long behind them, merging with the night. The grave is unmarked. No one will visit. But the night remembers. It holds the echo of footsteps, the weight of unspoken words. Night funeral: not an ending, but a quiet joining of the soul to the dark, where peace is not found, but made.

In silence left by what has slipped away, / A different wisdom starts to bloom and stay. / The ache of absence, sharp as winter’s breath, / Can stir the soil of what comes after death— / Not just of people, but of dreams once clung, / Of roles outgrown, of songs forever unsung. / Yet in that void, a gentler voice takes root: / 'You are not what you lost, but what you choose.' / For loss removes the clutter we called need, / And plants the seeds of empathy and heed. / We learn to listen deeper, love more true, / To hold the moment, not the old façade. / Like forests cleared by fire, we rise anew, / Stronger in spirit, skies more vast in view. / So though we weep, we do not weep in vain— / Loss is the sculptor of the soul’s terrain.

When loss arrives, uninvited, stark, and bare, / It strips the world of color, leaves it gray. / But in that gray, a quiet truth takes air: / That letting go can clear the tangled way. / We think we lose when something slips from hand, / But sometimes loss is liberation’s guise— / A chain unhooked, a burden we’d not planned, / A chance to see with unclouded eyes. / The job, the love, the dream we thought was ours, / May block the path to who we’re meant to be. / Loss tears the curtain, shatters false frontiers, / And sets the captive spirit truly free. / So grief may come, and tears may fall like rain, / But from that soil, new purpose can remain.

Not every end is failure, not all pain / Is punishment. Sometimes, loss is release— / A tide that pulls back, cleansing what remains, / Creating space for inner strength to increase. / The child grown distant, the friend who moved away, / The chance we missed, the plan that fell apart— / These are not just wounds we must obey, / But teachers of a quieter, deeper art. / They show us how to hold life lightly, true, / To savor moments, not just grasp and keep. / Loss teaches depth, a perspective new, / And how to find the love that runs more deep. / For in the hush that follows what is gone, / We hear the voice of who we are—our own.

They say all things must pass, and still we clutch, / Resist the pull of change, the fall, the fade. / But loss, though harsh, can mean an unexpected clutch / Of grace—like shadows helping light be made. / The loss of youth reveals a calmer fire, / The end of love can birth self-knowledge true, / A failure clears the smoke of false desire, / And shows the path we always meant to pursue. / We build our lives on sand when we hold fast, / But loss can wash the illusion clean away. / Then, standing bare, we find we’re built to last, / Not in what’s lost, but in what we now say: / 'I am not broken. I am open. I am free. / And from this loss, I choose what comes to be.'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text: The ground does not promise to hold us forever, / nor should it. To stand on shifting soil / is to learn the language of roots—how they stretch, / restless, through dark cracks, seeking purchase. / People wish to be settled, yes— / to build homes on stone, to name the horizon, / to say *this is mine* and mean it. / But peace is a slow lullaby that sings us to sleep, / and sleep breeds silence, and silence, decay. / Only when the earth trembles beneath us, / when walls we trusted turn to dust, / do we remember how to move, how to choose, / how to rise with hands open to the unknown. / The traveler has no map but the wind; / the refugee knows the stars by heart. / Settled hearts grow moss; unsettled ones burn. / So let the foundations waver. / Let the familiar fade. / For in the trembling, in the not-knowing, / we are most alive— / unmoored, unmasked, awake— / and only then, in our beautiful unrest, / does the world whisper: *Now, you may begin.*

In quiet towns where fences stand unbroken, / and every path is paved and known, / people speak of comfort, of peace, of home. / Yet peace can be a prison, / and home, a cage with gilded bars. / They wish to be settled, rooted like oaks, / unmoving through the seasons. / But what grows in stillness but rot? / What blooms where no wind dares to stir? / It is the storm that cracks the seed, / the drought that drives roots deeper. / Only as long as we are unsettled— / hearts unanchored, minds unquiet— / do we reach, do we question, do we change. / The wanderer, with blistered feet and tired eyes, / sees more than the sleeper in silk. / The seeker, trembling at the edge of doubt, / holds more truth than the one who claims to know. / So let the ground shift. Let certainty fail. / For in the tremor of not-knowing, / in the ache of displacement, / lies the birth of becoming. / Hope does not live in stillness— / it dances in the chaos, / whispering: *You are not lost. You are free.*

They build their lives like walls— / brick by careful brick, / sealing out the wind, the rain, the unknown. / They call it safety. They call it home. / But a house without cracks lets in no light. / A heart without tremors feels nothing at all. / People wish to be settled, yes— / to silence the questions, to end the search. / Yet it is the search that shapes us, / the not-knowing that keeps us honest. / Only in the unsettled hours— / when belief crumbles, when paths vanish— / do we find the courage to choose again. / The compass spins, and for a moment, / there is terror. Then wonder. / For where once was certainty, now blooms possibility. / The migrant knows this. The dreamer, too. / They carry no permanent address, / only the quiet fire of becoming. / So let the old maps burn. / Let the familiar roads dissolve. / In the beautiful unrest of being unmoored, / we touch the edge of what might be. / And there, in the trembling, / hope stirs—alive, restless, / refusing to be settled.

Settled—like dust on shelves, / like stones in dry riverbeds, / like prayers repeated until they lose meaning. / People wish for stillness, for a world that stays put, / where every answer is known, and every door locked. / But stillness is the prelude to forgetting. / And forgetting is the death of wonder. / Only as long as they are unsettled— / hearts unquiet, spirits unbound— / is there room for awakening. / The traveler who never arrives sees every horizon. / The questioner who never finds the answer / learns the music of inquiry. / To be unsettled is to be awake— / to feel the world in its raw, shifting truth. / It is uncomfortable. prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text: The heart craves calm, a steady shore, / A harbor where the waves implore / No more to toss, no more to roam— / To settle is the soul’s first home. / But in that peace, a danger grows, / A quiet rust where motion froze. / For when the path is known, the map complete, / The mind forgets how to beat / With wonder, risk, or wild desire— / Safe fires warm but do not inspire. / It’s in the tremble of the unknown, / In rootless seeds that stand alone, / That vision sparks and courage climbs— / The unsettled spirit rewrites time. / When comfort grips with velvet chains, / The world contracts to measured plains. / But let the ground shift, let dreams collide, / And from the chaos, truth will ride. / So bless the doubt, the sleepless night, / The compass spinning toward the light. / For only when we’re unmoored, unsealed, / Can we become what we’ve yet to feel. / Be restless, then—don’t seek to land. / The soul grows only in the sand / That shifts beneath the wandering feet— / Hope lives where certainty and silence meet.

People wish to be settled, / roots deep in familiar soil, / but growth begins in trembling, / in the ache of unmarked toil. / They build their walls against the wind, / yet only storms can teach the tree / how far its branches might extend— / how strong it grows by bending. / To be unsettled is to wake, / to feel the world not as it seems, / but as it could be, vast and strange, / alive with fractured, hopeful dreams. / The clock ticks on, the routine hums, / but change arrives on restless feet. / No masterpiece was ever born / where comfort made the heart retreat. / So let the ground dissolve beneath, / let certainty collapse like sand. / For in the fall, the rise begins— / the unsettled soul commands. / There is no truth in stagnant pools, / no light within a sealed-up room. / The mind that questions, shakes, rebels— / that mind will pierce the coming bloom. / Be unquiet. Settled minds are quiet minds, / content with answers, free from binds / of questioning, of doubt, of fear— / but also free from vision clear. / For truth does not reside in stone, / nor in the place we’ve always known. / It flickers at the edge of sight, / in moments when we lose the light. / The traveler without a home / often finds the way back to the foam— / not of the sea, but of the soul, / where passion burns and makes us whole. / To be unsettled is to feel / the pulse of what is raw and real. / It’s in the stumble, in the fall, / that we hear the universe call. / No one finds stars by staying still— / they rise through motion, through the will / to wander, question, break, rebuild, / to face the storm and not be stilled. / So let the old foundations crack, / let comfort fade and courage act. / For only in the unknown’s grip / does hope ignite a single tip / of flame that grows to light the way— / unsettled hearts will save the day.

In every heart, a quiet plea: / to rest, to cease, to simply be. / No more to strive, no more to climb, / just steady breath, a constant time. / But stillness, held too long, turns cold— / a story finished, never told. / For hope lives not in what is gained, / but in the loss, the rearranged. / The settled life may seem complete, / yet lacks the spark, the pulse, the heat / that comes from standing on the edge, / from turning over every pledge. / To be unsettled is to see / the world anew, unchained, un-plea. / It is the wound that lets in light, / the fall that teaches how to fight. / The mind at ease forgets to dream; / the restless heart rewrites the scheme. / So bless the night, the doubt, the fray— / the soul must wander to find its way. / Let roots be torn, let paths be blurred— / salvation lies in being stirred. / For only when we’re unpossessed / by certainty, can we be blessed / with wonder, risk, and wild release— / unsettled lives create true peace.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long, / A silver thread through barren lands, a hymn in nature’s song. / I walked with blistered feet and heart, beneath a weight of years, / Chasing a hope I barely knew, drowned out by silent fears. / The rapids roared with memories, the eddies spun with pain, / Yet something in the water’s pulse kept calling me again. / It carried leaves of forgotten names and stones worn smooth by time, / And in its flow, I started to believe in love’s long climb. / Then through the mist, a figure rose, both stranger and my own— / You stood where waters gently stilled, a place I’d never known. / The river wound its ancient path, indifferent yet wise, / A silent guide through darkest nights beneath indifferent skies. / And now I know no journey’s lost when led by unseen grace, / For every wave that wore me down brought me to your embrace.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long, / A winding vein through thirsty earth, a seeker’s faithful song. / I crossed the deserts of my doubt, the mountains of my pride, / Each step a plea, each breath a vow to let love be my guide. / The current sang in midnight tones, a lullaby of loss, / Yet promised in its quiet depths a different kind of cross— / Not one of thorns or bitter pain, but passage into light, / A merging of two wandering souls beneath a shared moonlight. / When at last I saw your face reflected in the stream, / I wept for joy and sorrow, torn apart and whole again. / The river did not boast its role, nor claim to understand, / It simply flowed, as rivers do, and brought me to your hand. / Now we walk beside its waters, hand in hand, soul in soul, / Grateful for the winding path that made the broken whole.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long, / A serpentine companion through a world both fierce and wrong. / I cursed the rocks that cut my feet, the storms that chilled my skin, / But never once did I let go—the current pulled me in. / It danced through canyons carved by time, beneath a watchful moon, / And in its hush, I heard your name, a soft and steady tune. / I dreamed of you in quiet pools, in ripples, in the dew— / A vision born of longing, yet somehow true, somehow true. / Then one dawn, where waters slowed and kissed the golden sand, / There you stood, as if you'd waited since the making of the land. / No words were needed—just a glance, a smile, a silent vow— / The river knew what hearts like ours would never speak out loud. / Now we build our home nearby, where willows dip and sigh, / And thank the stream that never failed to guide me to your eye.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long, / A liquid road through tangled grief where I had wandered wrong. / It cut through forests thick with ghosts, where echoes called my name, / And every bend revealed a truth I’d tried so hard to tame. / The water bore the weight of years, the tears I’d never shed, / And in its flow, I slowly learned to lift my bowed-up head. / It didn’t rush, it didn’t plead—just moved with patient grace, / A mirror to the hidden path my soul had to embrace. / Then in a clearing, calm and bright, where sunlight kissed the shore, / I saw your eyes, two quiet pools I’d journeyed to adore. / You reached for me as if you’d known the trials I had crossed, / As if the river spoke to you in language never lost. / Now we stand where waters meet, two streams become one stream, / And every drop that brought me here fulfills a sacred dream.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,'

responses.text: The river led me to you though the way was hard and long, / Through tangled woods and thunder’s song, / Where roots like serpents coiled and clung, / And silence split by raven’s tongue. / I waded through the freezing tide, / My bones alight, my spirit tried, / Each step a prayer, each breath a plea— / That you would wait beyond the sea. / The current pulled with bitter hands, / Dragging doubt through shifting sands, / Yet something hummed beneath my skin— / A name I’d lost, a world within. / And when at last I saw your face, / Reflected in that sacred place, / The river stilled, the journey done— / Two souls reborn beneath one sun. / No more the ache, no more the fight, / Just dawnlight spilling soft and bright. / For though the path was scarred and long, / The river led me to you—where I belong.

Through canyons carved by time and rain, / The river sang your name again. / It pulled me west on bruised and bare feet, / Through storms that howled and winds that beat. / The way was long, the nights were cold, / My heart a story half-unfolded. / But in the current’s steady call, / I heard the echo of your voice, small yet tall. / It wound through valleys, deep and wide, / Like love that will not be denied. / Stones cut my skin, the branches tore, / Yet something kept me wanting more. / And when the water slowed and cleared, / There stood you—everything I feared / And dreamed and lost and sought and knew— / The river led me to you. / No map, no star, no guiding light, / Just water’s wisdom, deep and right. / Though the journey left its scars and throngs, / The river led me to you—where I belong.

I followed where the water ran, / A pilgrim drawn by nature’s plan. / The river carved a crooked line, / Like fate inscribed in ancient rhyme. / It tumbled down from mountain snows, / Through shadowed pines and fields of rose, / And though I stumbled, bruised and blind, / It carried echoes of your mind. / Each ripple seemed to whisper low, / 'Endure, beloved, do not go. / The path is long, the night is deep, / But love like yours will never sleep.' / So I pressed on through fog and flame, / Calling out your secret name. / And when the current reached the shore, / You stood there—waiting, whole, and more. / The river led me to you at last, / A journey meant to always last. / Though the way was hard and stretched so long, / The river led me to you—where I belong.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long, / A silver thread through ancient song. / I walked where willows wept and bent, / Through seasons lost and time half-spent. / The water sang a lullaby / Beneath a vast and storm-swept sky, / And though I faltered, broke, and bled, / It carried words my heart once said. / 'Keep going,' murmured every stream, / 'You’re closer now than in your dream.' / The rocks were sharp, the nights were wide, / But something in the flow replied. / And when the banks grew soft and near, / I saw your silhouette appear— / A vision born of hope and wrong, / The river led me to you all along. / No force on earth could have undone / The pull of water, fate, and sun. / Though the path was hard and stretched so long, / The river led me to you—where I belong.

From mountain source to ocean’s kiss, / The river mapped my road to this— / To you, who stood where waters cease, / A haven born of pain and peace. / I crossed the gorges, steep and grim, / With shadows clinging, dark and dim. / The current roared, a warning loud, / But love defied the thunder’s shroud. / I lost my way in mist and thorn, / My body battered, spirit worn, / Yet every eddy, every bend, / Seemed shaped to guide me to my end— / Not death, but life in your embrace, / A final, long-foreseen grace. / The river led me through the wrong / To find the one where I belong. / Though the journey left its marks and throngs, / The river led me to you—where I belong.
